Analyzing the Impact of Partial Sharing on the Resilience of Online Federated Learning Against Model Poisoning Attacks

Ehsan Lari, , Vinay Chakravarthi Gogineni, ,
Reza Arablouei, and Stefan Werner This work was supported by the Research Council of Norway. Part of this work has been presented to the 2024 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP), Seoul, South Korea, Apr. 2024 [DOI: 10.1109/ICASSP48485.2024.10447497]. (Corresponding author: Ehsan Lari.)Ehsan Lari and Stefan Werner are with the Department of Electronic Systems, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim 7491, Norway (e-mail: {ehsan.lari, stefan.werner}@ntnu.no). Stefan Werner is also with the Department of Information and Communications Engineering, Aalto University, 00076, Finland.Vinay Chakravarthi Gogineni is with the SDU Applied AI and Data Science, The Maersk Mc-Kinney Moller Institute, Faculty of Engineering, University of Southern Denmark, Odense 5230, Denmark (e-mail: vigo@mmmi.sdu.dk).Reza Arablouei is with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Pullenvale, QLD 4069, Australia (e-mail: reza.arablouei@csiro.au).
Abstract

We scrutinize the resilience of the partial-sharing online federated learning (PSO-Fed) algorithm against model-poisoning attacks. PSO-Fed reduces the communication load by enabling clients to exchange only a fraction of their model estimates with the server at each update round. Partial sharing of model estimates also enhances the robustness of the algorithm against model-poisoning attacks. To gain better insights into this phenomenon, we analyze the performance of the PSO-Fed algorithm in the presence of Byzantine clients, malicious actors who may subtly tamper with their local models by adding noise before sharing them with the server. Through our analysis, we demonstrate that PSO-Fed maintains convergence in both mean and mean-square senses, even under the strain of model-poisoning attacks. We further derive the theoretical mean square error (MSE) of PSO-Fed, linking it to various parameters such as stepsize, attack probability, number of Byzantine clients, client participation rate, partial-sharing ratio, and noise variance. We also show that there is a non-trivial optimal stepsize for PSO-Fed when faced with model-poisoning attacks. The results of our extensive numerical experiments affirm our theoretical assertions and highlight the superior ability of PSO-Fed to counteract Byzantine attacks, outperforming other related leading algorithms.

Index Terms:
Online federated learning, Byzantine clients, partial-sharing, linear regression, model-poisoning.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1, 2] is a distributed learning paradigm that enables a network of devices, such as smartphones, internet of things (IoT) nodes, and media streamers, to jointly learn a global model without the need to directly disclose their local raw data to the server or other devices. FL is particularly beneficial when data is distributed across numerous devices, and conducting centralized training by transferring the data to the server is unfeasible or impractical [3, 4]. FL exhibits two key features: the ability to handle heterogeneous data, such as non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) or unbalanced data, and the ability to run on heterogeneous devices that may have limited resources [5, 6, 7].

The communication load in FL refers to the volume of data transmitted between the central server and participating devices during training. It can affect the efficiency and scalability of FL in real-world applications as excessive data transmission may escalate resource usage and the cost associated with trainingÂ [8, 9, 10]. Several algorithms have been proposed to alleviate the communication load in FL. Among them, sign stochastic gradient descent (SignSGD)Â [11, 12] utilizes sign-based gradient compressors to lower the communication and computational costs of FL. Compressive sensing FL (CS-Fed)Â [13] reduces the communication load using 111-bit compressive sensing in analog aggregation transmissions. Quantile sketch FL (QS-Fed)Â [14] improves communication efficiency by compressing model updates using a count sketch. Online-Fed [15] enhances communication efficiency by engaging only a randomly selected subset of clients to communicate with the server in each iteration. However, the aforementioned works do not consider the potential presence of adversaries within the network who may seek to undermine the learning process. This can be through tampering with message exchanges or intentionally providing corrupted or incorrect information. Factoring in the possibility of malicious clients in the network is an important aspect of developing reliable and robust FL algorithms.

In network environments, Byzantine clients are those that act unpredictably or with malicious intent. Such clients can disrupt normal operations by sending misleading information or not following established protocols. This behavior poses significant risks to the FL process, potentially leading to disruption or degraded performanceÂ [16, 17]. Byzantine clients can jeopardize the integrity and reliability of the global model in FL. They may engage in deceptive practices, such as submitting false or inconsistent gradients or model weights during updates, or even initiating denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, all of which can compromise the integrity and effectiveness of the FL processÂ [18, 19, 20]. To mitigate the impact of Byzantine clients in FL, various strategies have been proposed. These include the use of robust aggregate statistics, the assignment of trust scores to individual clients, and the utilization of historical information to recover from Byzantine attacksÂ [21, 22].

Byzantine clients may launch a wide range of adversarial attacks such as data-poisoning, model-poisoning, and label-poisoningÂ [23, 24]. Data-poisoning attacks involve the injection of malicious data into the training dataset [25, 26]. Evasion attacks involve manipulating input data to undermine the generalizability of the learned model while evading detectionÂ [27]. Backdoor attacks involve embedding hidden trigger mechanisms within the model that can induce targeted malicious behaviorÂ [28]. Inference-time attacks, such as membership inference, aim to uncover whether a specific data point has been used in training, raising privacy concerns [29, 30].

Attacks can also target network infrastructure, such as distributed DoS attacks and man-in-the-middle attacks, disrupting services or intercepting communicationsÂ [31]. Model-poisoning attacks, where Byzantine clients manipulate model updates during training, are prominent examplesÂ [32]. Defense strategies against model-poisoning attacks in FL are reviewed inÂ [32], categorized into evaluation methods for local model updates and aggregation methods for the global model. In evaluation methods, the server examines client submissions without having access to local client data, which poses challenges to their applicability. In aggregation methods, the server adjusts the local model updates based on certain criteria or utilizes relevant statistical methods. Robust aggregation techniques using median or trimmed mean can mitigate the impact of malicious clients on the global model [33]. Blockchain-assisted aggregation schemes can also help cope with network attacks but often incur high communication load or computational complexityÂ [34].

A SignSGD-based communication-efficient FL algorithm has recently been proposed in [35] that exhibits resilience to Byzantine attacks. However, it assumes the consistent participation of all clients in every FL iteration, which may not align with the practical realities of FL, particularly in scenarios where clients (such as mobile or IoT devices) have limited resources in terms of energy or computational capacity. Therefore, there is a notable gap in the current FL research: the need for communication-efficient FL algorithms that are robust against model-poisoning attacks without imposing additional computational burden on clients. Addressing this gap can make FL more accessible and practical for a wider range of devices, especially those with constrained resources, and enhance the robustness and scalability of FL systems in real-world applications.

In this paper, we analyze the performance of the partial-sharing online FL (PSO-Fed) algorithmÂ [9, 8, 36], particularly in the face of Byzantine attacks. Our analysis reveals that partial sharing in online FL, while primarily aimed at enhancing communication efficiency, also offers the added advantage of mitigating the adverse effects of model-poisoning attacks. Through rigorous theoretical analysis, we demonstrate that PSO-Fed can converge in both mean and mean-square senses, even when subjected to model-poisoning attacks. In addition, we derive the theoretical steady-state mean square error (MSE) of PSO-Fed. A key finding of our analysis is the identification of a non-trivial optimal stepsize for PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks. Contrary to the common behavior of stochastic gradient descent algorithms where a smaller stepsize often results in enhanced performance, in the case of PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks, a smaller stepsize does not automatically equate to better estimation accuracy. This is a departure from the norm observed in gradient-descent-based algorithms, where smaller stepsizes are commonly used to enhance performance, often at the cost of a slower convergence rate. We provide a theoretical calculation of the optimal stepsize. To validate our theoretical insights, we conduct extensive numerical experiments using synthetic non-IID data. The experimental outcomes confirm our theoretical predictions and show that PSO-Fed exhibits greater resilience to Byzantine attacks compared to other state-of-the-art algorithms, including Online-FL, all while avoiding any additional computational overhead.

We organize the remainder of this paper as follows. In section II, we provide an overview of the system model, PSO-Fed algorithm, and model-poisoning attacks. In section III, we evaluate the robustness of PSO-Fed against Byzantine attacks by analyzing its theoretical mean and mean-square convergence. In this section, we also calculate PSO-Fedâ€™s theoretical steady-state MSE and optimal stepsize. In section IV, we verify our theoretical findings through a series of numerical experiments. In these experiments, we evaluate the performance of PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks through both theoretical predictions and numerical simulations. Finally, in section V, we present some concluding remarks.

II Preliminaries

In this section, we first describe the considered system model. We then briefly outline the PSO-Fed algorithmÂ [9], which is a communication-efficient variant of the Online-Fed algorithmÂ [15]. Afterward, we define the model-poisoning Byzantine attack within the context of FL and probe its impact on the model update equations of PSO-Fed.

II-B PSO-Fed

In PSO-Fed, to reduce the communication load, the server only sends a portion of the global model estimate to the clients. Similarly, the clients transmit parts of their local model estimates to the server. The model parameters exchanged between client kğ‘˜k and the server at iteration nğ‘›n are specified using a diagonal selection matrix with Mğ‘€M ones, which is denoted by ğ’k,nâˆˆâ„DÃ—Dsubscriptğ’ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ·ğ·{\bf S}_{k,n}\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times D}. The positions of the ones on the diagonal determine which model parameters are shared with the server at each iteration. They can be selected arbitrarily or in a round-robin fashion as in [37, 38] such that the model parameters are exchanged between each client and the server, on average, Mğ‘€M times in every Dğ·D iterations. Therefore, the probability of any model parameter being shared with the server in any iteration is pe=M/Dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘€ğ·p_{e}=M/D.

II-C Model-Poisoning Attacks

We denote the set of potential Byzantine clients within the network as ğ’®Bsubscriptğ’®ğµ\mathcal{S}_{B}. To represent the presence or absence of Byzantine behavior in a client, we use the indicator variable Î²ksubscriptğ›½ğ‘˜\beta_{k}, where Î²k=1subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜1\beta_{k}=1 indicates that client kğ‘˜k belongs to the set ğ’®Bsubscriptğ’®ğµ\mathcal{S}_{B} (i.e., is a Byzantine client), and Î²k=0subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜0\beta_{k}=0 otherwise. The total number of Byzantine clients in the network is denoted by |ğ’®B|subscriptğ’®ğµ|\mathcal{S}_{B}|. These Byzantine clients seek to poison the global model (i.e., undermine its accuracy) by sporadically sending corrupt local model estimates to the server. We assume that the Byzantine clients possess the accurate local model estimates. More specifically, we consider a scenario where, in each iteration, every Byzantine client deliberately corrupts its local model estimate by perturbing it, before sending it to the server. This corruption is conducted with a certain probability of attack, denoted by pasubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{a}. Consequently, we represent the model update shared by any Byzantine client asÂ [39]

The probability of a Byzantine client corrupting its local estimate can be modeled using a Bernoulli random variable Ï„k,nsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘›\tau_{k,n}. This variable takes the value of 111 with probability pasubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{a} indicating the occurrence of an attack, and 00 otherwise. Hence, given that each Byzantine client transmits a corrupted local model estimate to the server with a probability of pasubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{a} when selected by the server, in scenarios where Byzantine clients are present in the network, the global model update of PSO-Fed, (4c), can be rewritten as

where

To make the analysis tractable, we adopt the following commonly used assumptions.

A1: The input vectors of each client, ğ±k,nsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘›{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}, originate from a wide-sense stationary multivariate random process characterized by the covariance matrix ğ‘k=ğ”¼â€‹[ğ±k,nâ€‹ğ±k,nâŠº]subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘›âŠº{\bf R}_{k}=\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}{\mathbf{x}}_{k,n}^{\intercal}].

A2: The observation noise, Î½k,nsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜ğ‘›\nu_{k,n}, and perturbation signal, ğœ¹k,nsubscriptğœ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘›\bm{\delta}_{k,n}, both follow identical and independent distributions. They are also independent of all other stochastic variables.

A3: The selection matrices, ğ’k,nsubscriptğ’ğ‘˜ğ‘›\mathbf{S}_{k,n}, of all clients and iterations are independent of each other.

The partial sharing of model parameters, scheduling of clients, statistics of input data, and value of stepsize impact the first and second terms on the RHS ofÂ (III-C), â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} and â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}. The observation noise influences the first and third terms, â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} and â„°ğš¯subscriptâ„°ğš¯\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\Theta}}, with the latter term being solely due to this noise. Moreover, the effect of model-poisoning attacks by Byzantine clients on the steady-state MSE of PSO-Fed is confined to the second term, â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}, which is induced by these attacks.

Remark 1: Considering (III-B) and the calculation of ğ“ ğ“’subscriptğ“ ğ“’{\bm{\mathcal{Q}}}_{\bm{\mathcal{C}}} in Appendix C, both partial sharing and client scheduling have a diminishing effect on ğğ\bm{\omega}. The lower the probability of sharing each entry of the model parameter vector, pe=MDsubscriptğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘€ğ·p_{e}=\frac{M}{D}, the smaller the entries of ğğ\bm{\omega} are. Therefore, (III-C) suggests that partial sharing can indeed endow online FL with enhanced resilience to model-poisoning attacks. However, partial sharing also affects â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} and increases its value as shown in [8, Fig. 1(a)]. This makes it hard to straightforwardly determine the overall impact of partial sharing on the steady-state MSE of PSO-Fed in scenarios involving model-poisoning attacks, by only analyzing (III-C). To gain deeper insights and validate these theoretical predictions, we undertake comprehensive simulations in section IV.

III-D Optimal Stepsize

In the absence of model-poisoning attacks where â„°ğ=0subscriptâ„°ğ0\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}=0, â„°â„°\mathcal{E} is a monotonically increasing function of the stepsize Î¼ğœ‡\mu, given (30) is satisfied. However, under model-poisoning attacks, the existence of â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} disrupts this monotonicity. It amplifies â„°â„°\mathcal{E} for smaller values of Î¼ğœ‡\mu and shifts the point of minimal â„°â„°\mathcal{E} from Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0 to a larger Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0. Consequently, this leads to the emergence of a non-trivial optimal stepsize that results in the minimum â„°â„°\mathcal{E} when facing model-poisoning attacks. We denote this optimal stepsize as Î¼âˆ—superscriptğœ‡\mu^{*}.

(37)

IV Simulation Results

To verify our theoretical findings, we conduct several numerical experiments. We also compare the performance of the PSO-Fed algorithm with that of the Online-Fed, SignSGD, CS-Fed, and QS-Fed algorithms within a federated network comprising K=50ğ¾50K=50 or 100100100 clients and a model parameter vector of size D=5ğ·5D=5. Each client possesses non-IID data vectors ğ±k,nsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘›\mathbf{x}_{k,n} and their associated response values yk,nsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘›y_{k,n}, which are interconnected as perÂ (1) with model parameter vector ğ°=1Dâ€‹[1,â‹¯,1]âŠºâˆˆâ„Dğ°1ğ·superscript1â‹¯1âŠºsuperscriptâ„ğ·\mathbf{w}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{D}}[1,\cdots,1]^{\intercal}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}. Each entry of ğ±k,nsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘›\mathbf{x}_{k,n} for each client kğ‘˜k is drawn from a zero-mean Gaussian distribution with variance Ï‚k2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜2\varsigma_{k}^{2}, where Ï‚k2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜2\varsigma_{k}^{2} itself is sampled from a uniform distribution between 0.20.20.2 and 1.21.21.2, denoted as ğ’°â€‹(0.2,1.2)ğ’°0.21.2\mathcal{U}(0.2,1.2). In addition, the observation noise Î½k,nsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜ğ‘›\nu_{k,n} is zero-mean IID Gaussian with variance ÏƒÎ½k2superscriptsubscriptğœsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜2\sigma_{\nu_{k}}^{2} drawn from ğ’°â€‹(0.005,0.025)ğ’°0.0050.025\mathcal{U}(0.005,0.025). In the conducted experiments, only M=1ğ‘€1M=1 entry of the model parameter vector is shared per iteration, unless specified differently.

We evaluate the performance of the considered algorithms on the serverâ€™s side by employing a test dataset consisting of Nt=50subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡50N_{t}=50 instances {ğ—Ë˜,ğ²Ë˜}Ë˜ğ—Ë˜ğ²\{\breve{\mathbf{X}},\breve{\mathbf{y}}\} and calculating the test MSE at the server as

1Ntâ€‹â€–ğ²Ë˜âˆ’ğ—Ë˜âŠºâ€‹ğ°nâ€–22.1subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptnormË˜ğ²superscriptË˜ğ—âŠºsubscriptğ°ğ‘›22\displaystyle\frac{1}{N_{t}}\ \|\breve{\mathbf{y}}-\breve{\mathbf{X}}^{\intercal}\mathbf{w}_{n}\|^{2}_{2}. (38)

We also evaluate the performance of PSO-Fed on the client side using (4a) and calculating the network-wide average steady-state MSE as

1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=1Klimnâ†’âˆÏµk,n2.1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptâ†’ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘˜ğ‘›2\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\ \sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\epsilon_{k,n}^{2}. (39)

In our first experiment, we examine the effect of different numbers of Byzantine clients |ğ’®B|subscriptğ’®ğµ|\mathcal{S}_{B}| on the steady-state test MSE for PSO-Fed, Online-Fed, SignSGD, CS-Fed, and QS-Fed. In this experiment, We have K=100ğ¾100K=100 clients. In every iteration nğ‘›n, the server randomly selects a set of |ğ’®n|=5subscriptğ’®ğ‘›5|\mathcal{S}_{n}|=5 clients to participate in FL, with each client having an equal probability of being selected. In addition, all Byzantine clients are characterized by model-poisoning noise variance of ÏƒB2=0.25superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25 and attack probability of pa=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘1p_{a}=1. In each iteration, we allocate the same communication budget to all algorithms. Therefore, to allow all algorithms converge to their lowest steady-state MSD within 300030003000 iterations, we set Î¼=0.15ğœ‡0.15\mu=0.15 for PSO-Fed, Online-Fed, CS-Fed and QS-Fed, and Î¼=0.08ğœ‡0.08\mu=0.08 for SignSGD at all clients. According to (30), the maximum stepsize ensuring the mean-square convergence of PSO-Fed in this experiment is Î¼mâ€‹aâ€‹x=0.245subscriptğœ‡ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥0.245\mu_{max}=0.245. The results displayed in Fig.Â 1 indicate that PSO-Fed outperforms the existing algorithms across all considered number of Byzantine clients. Notably, Online-Fed and PSO-Fed perform similarly when there is no Byzantine client or poisoning attack (i.e., ÏƒB2=0superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20\sigma_{B}^{2}=0). However, the performance of Online-Fed deteriorates more than PSO-Fed as the number of Byzantine clients increases. While CS-Fed performs closely to PSO-Fed in our experiment, it is important to note that the computational complexity of CS-Fed exceeds that of PSO-Fed.

In our second experiment, we examine the impact of the number of shared entries, Mğ‘€M, on the steady-state test MSE of PSO-Fed. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50ğ¾50K=50 clients, D=5ğ·5D=5, |ğ’®B|âˆˆ{5,15}subscriptğ’®ğµ515|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{5,15\} Byzantine clients, attack strength ÏƒB2=0.5superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20.5\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.5, and attack probability pa=0.2subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.2p_{a}=0.2. The results are shown in Fig.Â 3. We observe that increasing Mğ‘€M leads to higher steady-state test MSE. In addition, PSO-Fed exhibits greater resilience to model-poisoning attacks compared to Online-Fed, without incurring any extra computational or communication burden on the clients. This experiment corroborates our theoretical findings discussed in section III-C.

In our third experiment, we investigate the effect of varying the attack strength ÏƒB2superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2\sigma_{B}^{2} on the network-wide average steady state MSE. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50ğ¾50K=50 clients, D=5ğ·5D=5, |ğ’®B|âˆˆ{5,15}subscriptğ’®ğµ515|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{5,15\} Byzantine clients, attack strength ÏƒB2âˆˆ{0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1}superscriptsubscriptğœğµ200.250.50.751\sigma_{B}^{2}\in\{0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1\}, and attack probability pa=0.2subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.2p_{a}=0.2. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results depicted in Fig.2 align closely with our theoretical predictions. We notice an upward trend in the network-wide average steady-state MSE as the attack strength or the number of Byzantine clients increases. In addition, the presence of |ğ’®B|=Î±1subscriptğ’®ğµsubscriptğ›¼1|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=\alpha_{1} Byzantine clients with an attack strength of ÏƒB2=Î²1superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2subscriptğ›½1\sigma_{B}^{2}=\beta_{1} results in the same MSE as having |ğ’®B|=Î±2subscriptğ’®ğµsubscriptğ›¼2|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=\alpha_{2} Byzantine clients with an attack strength ÏƒB2=Î²2superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2subscriptğ›½2\sigma_{B}^{2}=\beta_{2}, provided that the condition Î±1â€‹Î²1=Î±2â€‹Î²2subscriptğ›¼1subscriptğ›½1subscriptğ›¼2subscriptğ›½2\alpha_{1}\beta_{1}=\alpha_{2}\beta_{2} is met.

In our fourth experiment, we explore how the attack probability pasubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{a} influences the steady-state test MSE of PSO-Fed, considering different numbers of shared entries Mâˆˆ{1,5}ğ‘€15M\in\{1,5\}, with the number of Byzantine clients set to |ğ’®B|=5subscriptğ’®ğµ5|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=5 and attack strength to ÏƒB2=0.25superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25. The results, presented in Fig. 5, align with observations from the previous experiment, showing that an increase in the attack probability leads to a higher MSE. Moreover, partial sharing (i.e., when M<Dğ‘€ğ·M<D) enhances the resilience against model-poisoning attacks as elaborated upon in section III-C.

In our fifth experiment, we investigate the impact of attack probability pasubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{a} on the steady-state test MSE of PSO-Fed, considering different numbers of Byzantine clients |ğ’®B|âˆˆ{5,15}subscriptğ’®ğµ515|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{5,15\} and setting the attack strength as ÏƒB2=0.25superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25. The results shown in Fig. 4 indicate that increasing the attack probability increases the steady-state MSE.

In our sixth experiment, we evaluate the performance of PSO-Fed using different stepsize values and Byzantine client numbers in the presence or absence of model-poisoning attacks. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50ğ¾50K=50 clients, D=5ğ·5D=5, attack strength ÏƒB2=0.25superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20.25\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.25, attack probability pa=0.25subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.25p_{a}=0.25. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results illustrated in Fig.Â 6, show that with no model-poisoning attack (|ğ’®B|=0subscriptğ’®ğµ0|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=0), the larger the stepsize Î¼ğœ‡\mu, the worse PSO-Fed performs, a trend consistent with gradient descent optimization methods. However, with model-poisoning attacks (|ğ’®B|>0subscriptğ’®ğµ0|\mathcal{S}_{B}|>0), the performance first improves with an increase in Î¼ğœ‡\mu, then deteriorates when Î¼ğœ‡\mu grows larger. This observation confirms the existence of an optimal stepsize Î¼âˆ—superscriptğœ‡\mu^{*} that ensures the best performance of PSO-Fed under model-poisoning attacks. By calculating the optimal stepsize using (37), we determine Î¼âˆ—â‰ˆ0.03superscriptğœ‡0.03\mu^{*}\approx 0.03, which corresponds to the experimental results.

In our seventh experiment, we analyze the performance of PSO-Fed using different stepsizes in the presence or absence of model-poisoning attacks, considering different attack strengths ÏƒB2superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2\sigma_{B}^{2}. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50ğ¾50K=50 clients, D=5ğ·5D=5, |ğ’®B|=5subscriptğ’®ğµ5|\mathcal{S}_{B}|=5 Byzantine clients, and attack probability of pa=0.25subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.25p_{a}=0.25. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results, presented in Fig.Â 7, echo the observations from the previous experiment: without a poisoning attack (ÏƒB2=0superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20\sigma_{B}^{2}=0), PSO-Fedâ€™s performance decreases as the stepsize Î¼ğœ‡\mu increases. Conversely, with model-poisoning attacks (ÏƒB2>0superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20\sigma_{B}^{2}>0), performance initially improves with an increase in Î¼ğœ‡\mu but begins to decline as Î¼ğœ‡\mu is further increased. This pattern confirms the existence of an optimal stepsize Î¼âˆ—superscriptğœ‡\mu^{*} for scenarios with model-poisoning attacks. Using (37) to estimate the optimal stepsize, we find Î¼âˆ—â‰ˆ0.03superscriptğœ‡0.03\mu^{*}\approx 0.03, corresponding to the experimentâ€™s findings. This experiment also reinforces our conclusion following the third experiment that identical attack properties result in the same MSE.

In our eighth experiment, we investigate the impact of the commonly-adopted small stepsize approximation (SSA) on predicting the performance of PSO-Fed in the presence or absence of model-poisoning attacks. Specifically, we assume that higher orders of Î¼ğœ‡\mu are negligible when computing ğ“•ğ“•{\bm{\mathcal{F}}} via (18). We then compare the simulated network-wide average MSE of PSO-Fed with the corresponding theoretical predictions with or without SSA. We simulate PSO-Fed with K=50ğ¾50K=50 clients, D=5ğ·5D=5, attack probability pa=0.25subscriptğ‘ğ‘0.25p_{a}=0.25, attack strength ÏƒB2=0.5superscriptsubscriptğœğµ20.5\sigma_{B}^{2}=0.5, and numbers of Byzantine clients |ğ’®B|âˆˆ{0,10}subscriptğ’®ğµ010|\mathcal{S}_{B}|\in\{0,10\}. The server randomly selects 555 clients in each iteration. The results in Fig.Â 8 reveal that, when Î¼ğœ‡\mu is sufficiently small, SSA does not hinder the accurate prediction of steady-state MSE even without the knowledge of the 444th moment of the input vector, ğ“—ğ“—\bm{\mathcal{H}}. However, as the stepsize increases, discrepancies arise in both scenarios, with and without model-poisoning attacks, diverging from the ideal case.

In our final experiment, we investigate the effect of partial sharing on different terms of MSE (III-C), namely, â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} and â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}}, in the presence of model-poisoning attacks. We compute both terms using the same setup as in our second experiment. The results depicted in Fig.Â 9 show that decreasing the number of shared parameters considerably lowers â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}}, significantly mitigating the impact of model-poisoning attacks. However, sharing fewer entries increases â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}}. Still, the benefits of partial sharing in reducing â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} are more substantial, leading to reduced MSE. Note that â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}} remains unchanged across both considered cases, as it depends solely on scheduling and data noise. Finally, this experiment corroborates our theoretical findings and confirms our assertions regarding the effect of partial sharing on â„°ğsubscriptâ„°ğ\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\omega}} and â„°Ï•subscriptâ„°bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\phi}}, as discussed at the end of sectionÂ III-C.

V Conclusion

We conducted a theoretical analysis of the recently proposed PSO-Fed algorithm to examine its resilience to model-poisoning (Byzantine) attacks imparted by partial sharing. In our analysis, we considered a linear regression task with the local objective function of each client defined as an empirical risk. We showed that, even under Byzantine attacks, PSO-Fed converges in both mean and mean-square senses, given an appropriate choice of stepsize. More importantly, we showed that, in the presence of Byzantine clients, the steady-state MSE of PSO-Fed is significantly smaller than that of the Online-Fed algorithm, which does not feature partial sharing. Our theoretical analysis also uncovered the existence of a non-trivial optimal stepsize for PSO-Fed in the presence of model-poisoning attacks The simulation results corroborated our theoretical findings regarding PSO-Fedâ€™s effectiveness against Byzantine attacks as well as the accuracy of the theoretically predicted values of its steady-state MSE and optimal stepsize.
